title: HTTP Parameter Pollution using semicolons in iframe element at hackerone.com/careers allows loading external Greenhouse forms

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
I noticed that HackerOne career pages loads it's application forms from Greenhouse.io via an iframe. The **gh_jid** parameter value is taken into the iframe element for the token parameter in the iframe URL (boards.greenhouse.io). Any html characters are escaped in order to avoid XSS (and possibly also to avoid any additional parameters to be included to avoid that parameters are overridden). However, I have discovered that I could load any form on the page.

**Description (Include Impact):**
Basically, you can load any form of Greenhouse.io via a GET request. I am not entirely sure how Greenhouse works (I also can not discover how it actually works since you only have paid subscriptions at Greenhouse), but you might also be able to craft pages instead of forms only (which would be more effective for a phishing attack, than only a form).

This happens because due to the fact that you can include a semicolon in the iframe element. As stated on https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_string, a semicolon can be used besides the ampersand in URLs embedded in HTML. 

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Go to https://www.hackerone.com/careers?gh_jid=795069;for=airbnb for example.
2. You will notice an AIrbnb application form being loaded on the page.

(I sadly could not test my own forms, hence why I have used Airbnb forms to load on the page, as stated above).

A fix would be to either escape the semicolon, or to adjust the position of the for parameter in the iframe URL to avoid the URL being overridden. 

Example for changing the order of the URLs:

* https://boards.greenhouse.io/embed/job_app?for=hackerone&token=795069;for=airbnb&b=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hackerone.com%2Fcareers (this would load the form as the parameter is overridden).

with

* https://boards.greenhouse.io/embed/job_app?token=795069;for=airbnb&b=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hackerone.com%2Fcareers&for=hackerone (this would not load the form as the parameter is not overridden).


PS: After my pretty much failed report (#289999) (which was valid, but the way I described the vulnerability made it invalid), I appreciate any feedback on the quality of my report! Thanks in advance.

## Impact

An attacker can load any other forms on the page, and possibly craft pages as well, but that depends on how Greenhouse.io actually works with it's forms. Therefore, a phishing attack would be possible.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
I noticed that HackerOne career pages loads it's application forms from Greenhouse.io via an iframe. The gh_jid parameter value is taken into the iframe element for the token parameter in the iframe URL (boards.greenhouse.io). Any html characters are escaped in order to avoid XSS (and possibly also to avoid any additional parameters to be included to avoid that parameters are overridden). However, I have discovered that I could load any form on the page.

Description (Include Impact):
Basically, you can load any form of Greenhouse.io via a GET request. I am not entirely sure how Greenhouse works (I also can not discover how it actually works since you only have paid subscriptions at Greenhouse), but you might also be able to craft pages instead of forms only (which would be more effective for a phishing attack, than only a form).

This happens because due to the fact that you can include a semicolon in the iframe element. As stated on https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_string, a semicolon can be used besides the ampersand in URLs embedded in HTML.

Steps To Reproduce

  1. Go to https://www.hackerone.com/careers?gh_jid=795069%3Bfor=airbnb for example.
  2. You will notice an AIrbnb application form being loaded on the page.

(I sadly could not test my own forms, hence why I have used Airbnb forms to load on the page, as stated above).

A fix would be to either escape the semicolon, or to adjust the position of the for parameter in the iframe URL to avoid the URL being overridden.

Example for changing the order of the URLs:

  • https://boards.greenhouse.io/embed/job_app?for=hackerone&token=795069%3Bfor=airbnb&b=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hackerone.com%2Fcareers (this would load the form as the parameter is overridden).

with

  • https://boards.greenhouse.io/embed/job_app?token=795069%3Bfor=airbnb&b=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hackerone.com%2Fcareers&for=hackerone (this would not load the form as the parameter is not overridden).

PS: After my pretty much failed report (#289999) (which was valid, but the way I described the vulnerability made it invalid), I appreciate any feedback on the quality of my report! Thanks in advance.

Impact

An attacker can load any other forms on the page, and possibly craft pages as well, but that depends on how Greenhouse.io actually works with it's forms. Therefore, a phishing attack would be possible.

additional_data.old_title: Able to load any form at hackerone.com/careers of Greenhouse
additional_data.new_title: Able to load any form of Greenhouse at hackerone.com/careers

activities.message: Sweet, well done █████████! We were able to reproduce this vulnerability and will get back to you when we have an update.
activities.markdown_message: Sweet, well done █████████! We were able to reproduce this vulnerability and will get back to you when we have an update.

activities.message: Hi █████████ - this should be fixed now. Can you confirm? Thanks again for bringing this to our attention. I'll double check with some other people on our side what the actual severity is. Even though this was unexpected, I'm unsure whether it could've actually be exploited in any way. We'll keep you posted. Thanks again!
activities.markdown_message: Hi █████████ - this should be fixed now. Can you confirm? Thanks again for bringing this to our attention. I'll double check with some other people on our side what the actual severity is. Even though this was unexpected, I'm unsure whether it could've actually be exploited in any way. We'll keep you posted. Thanks again!

activities.message: Hey @jobert! Seems like it is fixed. That is OK. I personally think there is an actual severity here, but I will let you guys discuss about it internally firstly. No problem, thanks for the quick resolution!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @jobert! Seems like it is fixed. That is OK. I personally think there is an actual severity here, but I will let you guys discuss about it internally firstly. No problem, thanks for the quick resolution!

activities.message:
Hey @jobert,

I've a simple question.

I've noticed that there are numerous of websites who are using this implementation of Greenhouse forms, by searching with a simple Google Dork Query. All of these websites were found vulnerable. Don't you think this should rather be fixed on @Greenhouse's side, by disallowing semicolons on the ``boards.greenhouse.io/embed`` endpoint?
activities.markdown_message:

I've noticed that there are numerous of websites who are using this implementation of Greenhouse forms, by searching with a simple Google Dork Query. All of these websites were found vulnerable. Don't you think this should rather be fixed on @Greenhouse's side, by disallowing semicolons on the boards.greenhouse.io/embed endpoint?

activities.message: ███████ Yeah, it might be worth reaching out to them at @greenhouse. Let me know if you need anything from us!
activities.markdown_message: ███████ Yeah, it might be worth reaching out to them at @greenhouse. Let me know if you need anything from us!

activities.message: Thanks for bringing this to our attention, creative find!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for bringing this to our attention, creative find!

activities.message:
@jobert

Alright, will do! Thank you for the bounty by the way! :)

@jobert

activities.message:
Hi @jobert,

I'd love to disclose this one soon, however as I have changed my name, I'd love to have references to my previous name removed/redacted.

Besides that, am I supposed to request public disclosure/permission from Greenhouse to disclose this report (as they have applied a fix by disallowing semicolons on the embed endpoint)? I personally don't think that would be required.

(Possibly the severity has to be updated as well. Did you already discuss the severity with your colleagues?)

activities.message:
> I'd love to disclose this one soon, however as I have changed my name, I'd love to have references to my previous name removed/redacted.

I just redacted your previous username - please confirm.

> Besides that, am I supposed to request public disclosure/permission from Greenhouse to disclose this report (as they have applied a fix by disallowing semicolons on the embed endpoint)?

I'll reach out to them and follow up with you once I hear back.

> Possibly the severity has to be updated as well.

We determined that there was no immediate way to exploit this. However, we ended up fixing it because we couldn't oversee potential future consequences. I believe the impact is still correct. Please let me know if you think I missed something.

Thanks and I'll get back to you soon!

activities.message: Hi @kapytein - @rongutierrez (Greenhouse) confirmed that we can disclose this report. We're ready when you are!

activities.message: Let's go, thank you for the smooth disclosure process @jobert! For those curious, I have attached a screenshot on how it looked like.

summaries.content: Using semicolons, I was able to override the `for` parameter in the iframe element. This allowed me to load external Greenhouse forms (which are not owned by HackerOne) on the page. Later on, a global fix was applied by Greenhouse on the `boards.greenhouse.io/embed/` endpoint.
summaries.content_html: Using semicolons, I was able to override the for parameter in the iframe element. This allowed me to load external Greenhouse forms (which are not owned by HackerOne) on the page. Later on, a global fix was applied by Greenhouse on the boards.greenhouse.io/embed/ endpoint.
